In 1938 a Yorkshire Authors Dinner was chaired by J.B. Priestley in Leeds. White roses, heather and bracken adorned the top table, a map of the county was placed behind Priestley and a vast Yorkshire pudding was brought in to the singing of ‚ÄòIlkla Moor Baht ‚ÄòAt‚Äô. 6/6 https://t.co/o3Z65bG034

Neville Cardus wrote: ‚ÄòAt Old Trafford, in 1926, 78,617 Lancashire and Yorkshire folk paid to watch this annual holiday argument ... dwellers in Lancashire and Yorkshire regarded the Roses match second in importance and family pride to none; England v Australia came second.‚Äô 5/6

Yorkshire and Lancashire county cricket clubs adopted roses as their cap badge. Lord Hawke, Yorkshire captain 1883-1910, described Roses matches as a ‚Äòjolly rivalry‚Äô. The fixture was at its peak between the world wars. (Pic Yorks v Lancs, Sheffield, August 1973) 4/6 https://t.co/ve23MCkm3R

The name ‚ÄòWars of the Roses‚Äô was popularised in the 19th century by novelist Sir Walter Scott in Ivanhoe and Anne of Geierstein, though there were much earlier references. Sometimes it was known as the Cousins‚Äô War. Jacobites later also adopted the white rose as a symbol. 3/6

In a famous scene in Shakespeare‚Äôs Henry VI Part One, Richard, duke of York, invites supporters to pick a white rose in London‚Äôs Temple Garden while a bitter rival, the duke of Somerset, does likewise with a red. (Painting by Henry Payne, 1908). 2/6 https://t.co/801RuX28H4

Roses were among various emblems used in the wars between the houses of York and Lancaster, not the most prominent ones, before Henry VII employed them to create his Tudor rose with red and white petals denoting reconciliation. 1/6 https://t.co/T7gn5OvmiX

That decline hit Trafford Park and made Manchester‚Äôs docks virtually redundant by the 1980s. 6/6

Industry grew along its banks, notably Trafford Park industrial estate, which employed 40,000 by the 1930s. Tonnage on the canal peaked in 1958 and declined after containerisation made ships too big to use it. (Pic: 5pm exodus from AEI, Trafford Park, 1962.) 5/6 https://t.co/nJPYhLcs0Y

Arguably, the biggest beneficiaries were the corporations of Salford and Stretford, which made no investment but were the main recipients of the rateable income it created. Gradually, traffic grew and it put a dent in Liverpool docks‚Äô income. (Pic: Barton Swing Aqueduct.) 4/6 https://t.co/w3m6boC6xt
The cost had soared from a projected ¬£8.4m to ¬£14.4m and some ordinary investors did not see a return until 1915. (Pic: Queen Victoria opening the canal). 3/6 https://t.co/UxPgMzyu7s
